newsitem.title: USA: Microsoft expands cable tv reach with Comcast deal.
newsitem.headline: Microsoft expands cable tv reach with Comcast deal.

text.p: Microsoft Corp. Monday expanded its foray into the cable television business with a $1 billion investment in Philadelphia's Comcast Corp., one of the biggest U.S. cable operators.
Microsoft Chairman Bill Gates described the deal as a chance to further the software giant's interest in providing multimedia services for home users.

"Our vision connecting the world of PCs and TVs has long included advanced broadband capabilities to deliver video, data and interactivity to the home," Gates said in a news release. "Comcast's integrated approach to cable distribution, programming and telecommunications complements that vision of linking PC and TV."
The deal gives Microsoft an avenue into the control and distribution of television programming, expanding on its MSNBC cable television joint venture with NBC.

For Comcast, the deal brings a "significant cash infusion" to pay off debt and repurchase stock, and access to Microsoft's expertise in computer operating systems and software management, said Comcast President Brian Roberts.
Roberts said the link-up with Microsoft will "help us facilitate the deployment of high-bandwidth applications and lead to more sophisticated services."

The "high bandwidth" Roberts referred to is cable lines that have huge capacity to carry data and could help the development of a high-speed Internet for consumers. The relatively low-bandwidth, low-speed lines now in place have kept a lid on the amount of traffic the Net can handle.
"We weren't out looking to raise capital," Roberts said in a telephone interview. "It's more of an opportunistic situation. We're not going to change our strategy."
Roberts said the investment by Microsoft would accelerate the company's deployment of digital television and cable computer modems.

Technology and media companies have been betting heavily on the growth of a consumer and business market for multimedia applications that range from e-mail to gobal videoconferences. Cable systems, with their heavy-duty coaxial cable lines, have higher-speed pipelines to handle such traffic than traditional telephone lines.

In the deal announced Monday, Microsoft will buy 24.6 million shares of Comcast Class A special common stock for $500 million, and $500 million of a new issue of Comcast Series B convertible preferred stock.

The Comcast Class B shares will have a 5.25 percent pay-in-kind dividend and will be initially convertible into 21.2 million shares, which equals an initial conversion price of $23.54 a share, the company said. The conversion price will increase proportionately to the amount of accrued dividends.
The deal is expected to close in "weeks, not longer," said Greg Maffei, Microsoft's vice president for corporate development, in a telephone interview.
Federal antitrust approval is not required because Microsoft is not buying voting shares of Comcast, he noted.
The investment gives Microsoft the right to a seat on Comcast's board but for now the software giant will post only an "observer," Maffei said.
Microsoft and Gates also will offer "guidance" to Comcast in its deployment of new technologies such as cable modems from At Home Corp., in which Comcast holds a stake, Maffei said.

Prior to the Comcast deal, Microsoft had agreed to invest in MSNBC as well as acquire WebTV, which has hardware to convert televisions into Internet receivers, in a $425 million deal. WebTV can also be used through cable systems to fine-tune interactive Internet applications.
Comcast's stock jumped $3.875 to $22.125, and Microsoft slipped $1.6775 $125.75 on Nasdaq in the afternoon.
